awd_titl_txt: How does stellar feedback drive interstellar turbulence and molecular hydrogen formation?
awd_abstract_narration:
Stars are formed in the interstellar medium (ISM) in dense and cold regions that are rich in different types of molecules. To understand how stars and planets form, it is essential to understand how their molecules form out of diffuse, neutral ISM gas. Once formed, stars inject energy into the ISM causing turbulence, which shakes and stirs the future stellar birthplaces. Astronomers study the neutral ISM using the 21-cm emission line of atomic hydrogen (HI). The researchers at the University of Wisconsin-Madison will investigate how interstellar turbulence affects the diffuse gas. They will use a new radio telescope in Australia to obtain HI observations of the Magellanic Clouds. The project team will also continue with the development of a comic strip for middle school students, entitled “Galaxy scouts: Spaceventures with Stella and Riley”.  This strip features excitement and products of science in daily life, with the key goal of enhancing societal scientific literacy. These materials will be publicly available.  By developing the comic strip and three activity books, the group will provide a unique introduction to STEM disciplines for elementary and middle school students.

This project has the following objectives. First, to quantify the influence of different astronomical sources on interstellar turbulence, the project will quantify the level of spatial variations of HI turbulent properties across the Magellanic Clouds by using a novel statistical method. Second, to provide direct constraints for numerical simulations of star formation, the exact modes of turbulent motions and scales of operations will be mapped across the Magellanic Clouds. This will constrain the fraction of turbulent energy that shakes, as opposed to stirs, the HI gas. Third, as molecular hydrogen forms from the atomic hydrogen structures affected by turbulent motions, the project will test theories that incorporate turbulence in the molecular hydrogen formation process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project is focused on science with the neutral hydrogen (HI) observations obtained with the new radio telescope in Australia, ASKAP. HI represents the key fuel for future star formation and observational constraints of HI physical properties are crucial for understanding the process of star formation and galaxy evolution in general. The Madison team has played a major role in ASKAP’s HI observations of cold gas in the Milky Way and nearby Magellanic Clouds. In particular, by utilizing the supercomputing capabilities at the University of Wisconsin, this project has produced HI images of the Magellanic Clouds with exceptional resolution and sensitivity that have enabled a whole array of science results.

Intellectual Merit: 

The high resolution and spatial dynamic range HI observations are revolutionizing our understanding of sources of interstellar turbulence and their modes of operation. The Madison team has developed a novel statistical method (the rolling spatial power spectrum) for connecting HI turbulent properties with specific astronomical sources. In another study, spatial variations of turbulent modes and scales were characterized for the first time across the Small Magellanic Cloud. This information is crucial to guide numerical simulations of star formation which currently mostly artificially drive interstellar turbulence.

The Madison team has also investigated properties of cold HI clouds in low density regions (mainly galaxy outskirts) of the Magellanic Clouds. By characterizing observed properties, the origin of these cold clouds was traced to expanding shells caused by recent star formation. As the shells propagate and interact with the surrounding medium, cold HI condenses and is found in the far galaxy outskirts. This mechanism is likely to explain the presence of cold gas in tidal tails found around interacting galaxies.

To interpret observed properties of HI in the vicinity of molecular clouds, the Madison team has used the latest high-resolution simulations. Several simulated molecular clouds were identified and correlations between the star formation rate and cold gas properties were characterized, with a goal of applying similar analysis on ASKAP's observational data. This project examined both physical properties of cold gas as a function of time, as well as the kinematics of cold neutral and molecular gas around molecular clouds.

 

Broader Impacts:

This project continued the development of a comic strip, "Galaxy scouts: Space-ventures with Stella and Riley", for middle school students featuring excitement and products of science in daily life, with the key goal of enhancing societal scientific literacy. The project developed a new comic strip, 3rd in the Galaxy Scouts series. Comic strips and activity books were used in many outreach events in Wisconsin, and are available for downloads on the project web site: 

https://galaxyscouts.wisc.edu/ .

A program evaluator conducted surveys of youth comic users and wrote project evaluation reports to quantify usefulness of comic strips as an educational tool. The reports are published on the project web site.
